Authors: Soesilo P.K.M., Gunadi W., Arimbi I.R.
Title: The effect of endorser and corporate credibility on perceived risk and consumer confidence: The case of technologically complex products
Affiliations: Business Management & Marketing Program, Management Department, BINUS Business School International Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Business Management Program, Management Department, BINUS Business School Master Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Soesilo, P.K.M., Business Management & Marketing Program, Management Department, BINUS Business School International Undergraduate Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Gunadi, W., Business Management Program, Management Department, BINUS Business School Master Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia; Arimbi, I.R., Business Management Program, Management Department, BINUS Business School Master Program, Bina Nusantara University, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: This research aims to examine the effect of corporate credibility and endorser credibility on consumers’ perceived risk and confidence in purchasing a technologically complex product. Further, this research investigates whether interaction of corporate and endorser credibility in ads can help consumers improve their perception toward the risk and confidence to purchase the product. An experimental study with a 2 (endorser credibility: high vs. low) × 2 (corporate credibility: high vs. low) full-factorial, between-subjects design was used to see the interaction effect of both corporate and endorser credibility on consumer perceived risk and consumer confidence to purchase a product. In a technologically complex product such as smartphones, consumers’ perceived risk was found to be lower when the product was produced by a credible company but endorsed by a less credible source, than when it was produced by a less credible company but endorsed by a more credible source. Consumer confidence in purchasing the product was also higher when the product was produced by a credible company but endorsed by a less credible source, than when it was produced by a less credible company but endorsed by a more credible source. © 2018, © 2018 Informa UK Limited, trading as Taylor & Francis Group.
Author Keywords: consumer confidence; Corporate credibility; Elaboration Likelihood Model; endorser credibility; perceived risk; purchase decision; technologically complex product
